fields.physical_description: Design: yellow card cut into 12 key shapes; 12 large circles and 12 small circles, 12 celluloid balls
fields.title: the game of bombardo; excitement and fun for all ages

fields.name:
Type: target, indoor sports
Subject: billiards

fields.history_note:
Introduced during the 1st World War and usually made within the Lord Robert's Workshops, the publishers added this note to the rules:-
THE MAKERS ARE INDEBTED TO THE LORD ROBERTS MEMORIAL WORKSHOPS FOR DISABLED SOLDIERS, SAILORS AND AIRMEN FOR PERMISSION TO RE-INTRODUCE THIS FAMOUS AND POPULAR GAME.

Maker's trademark - entwined HPG SERIES in a shield shape on rules.
fields.production_note: h p Gibson & sons ltd, london, copyright.  H P G SERIES IN SILVER KITE
fields.historical_context_note:
No. of Players: any
Equipment required: as stated

Rules: INSTRUCTIONS FOR THE GAME OF BOMBARDO

BOMBARDO is an extremely exciting game that will hold the attention and interest of both adults and children.
The game is mainly one of chance but it also makes a fascinating pastime for children.  It consists of various coloured cups which are knocked from their seating by a spinning top and a suspended striker.  There are 5 red cups, four blue cups, 2 yellow cups and one black cup.

TO COMMENCE PLAY
Place the coloured cups on top of their towers.  One player is elected to act as banker and winds the top, setting it spinning with a strong pull.
Players slect their colours on the stake chart which is printed on the inside of the lid.
One player now holds the rubber striker clear from the arch, the banker places the spinning top in the recess in the middle of the board and the striker is released on to the top.
The spinning top knocks the striker outwards and it commences to dislodge the cups from their towers.
Generally the last surviving colour is considered to be the winner, but there are various other methods which will suggest themselves.  When playing on the colours the numerals are ignored.
Various odds have been worked out and these are printed on the inside of the lid so that it can be used as a stake chart.

FOR CHILDREN
It is usual to ignore the colours and use the numerals.  Each child spins the top in turn and then withdraws the striker as soon as SIX cups have been knocked off.  The total scores of the remaining cups are then added together and this is written down as that player's score.  When each has had a turn the winner is the player with the highest score.
As in the adult game many other methods of finding the winner can be thought of, thus adding more variety and fun.

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS.
Do not take the game out of the box.  Erect the `arch' by fixing it into the two sockets provided.  Now check the length of string on which the rubber striker is suspended.  The striker should be approximately ¼in above the playing surface.  Fix all the metal towers into the holes around the edge of the board.  The `rings' on top of the towers should face the centre.  The colours can be situated in any position.
The spindle of the top should be oiled occasionally.
